title: Party Favor Soccer Style Whistle (no pea)

description.text:
I made this from scratch in Fusion 360 following this tutorial which I think was originally from autodesk inventor. http://www.instructables.com/id/3D-Printing-Whistle/

The Fusion 360 files are here: http://a360.co/2nkxavQ

I didn't put the pea in, although the one recommended in the tutorial is way oversized and doesn't vibrate like you would like because it is too heavy. I'll upload my printer settings for my Monoprice Maker Select Plus with eSun PLA+ material. I believe I used the medium 0.2 layer height because I needed to print 9 in less than 3 hours. I printed in glow in the dark green from another vendor at the 215C as well with very good results.

One whistle took 25 minutes on my printer. This is one reason I discarded the pea that was in the tutorial instead of finding an optimal size for it.

I extended the mouth and added a little spherical feature on one side. It should print without supports.

author: 3dball

description.text:
Yet an other fantastic original model by CaseStudyno8!

Now from a visual point of view it doesn't get any better than this. You can tell a lot of research and modeling expertise went into optimizing every single detail.
There are some models of this exact lightsaber floating around the interwebs but most of them would even be an offense to Jar Jar Binks to say the least.

But when it comes to fan made prop replicas there is always room for improvement - My contribution comes in form of rubberized grip and chamber.

I really like the original knurled design of the InnerGrip and LowerChamber which are supposed to be printed in black PLA or ABS. But I cannot imagine them to be quite comfy (and I guess Christopher Lee would agree).
As chance would have it, I had some flexible filament laying around from previous experiments. So why not use it on something "reasonable"?!

So to make this Remix, of course you need some TPE or TPU filament which can be somewhat pricy. I used Recreus FilaFlex which is like insane 40 €/$ for 0,5 kg.
And your machine has to be capable of printing rubber filament, which many Bowden extruders are limited or NOT!
In any case, carefully read my advice in the section below to help with printing the rubber sleeves.

WARNING: This as a complete overhaul not an update! My remix is not guaranteed to combine with the original parts! All required files are included here.

Printer:

Anet A6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

10 - 15%

Notes:

All original parts can be printed as you normally would a high quality movie or game prop. For this purpose I tend to lower the print speed (to as low as 25 - 30 mm/s) and set the layer height to 0.15 mm for good visual quality.

The cores of InnerGrip and LowerChamber can be printed much faster and at 0.2 layer height as they will be invisible later on.

The rubber hulls are somewhat more complicated and I strongly advise you to use my optimzed setting to get acceptable quality.

Use best practise for all flexible filaments:
-Use the lowest acceptable print speed (mine was 20 mm/s)
-TURN OFF RETRACTION completely as it does not work with TPE at all and will mess up your print
-Test out optimal hotend temperature for your material as TPE is prone to blistering when overheated
-Use Skirt not Brim for priming as latter is a pain in the a** to trim off and TPE sticks to the heatbed perfectly

Besides this you may have noticed the Hull files are not "hulls" but rather solid bodies. But thats not the way we are going to print them.
Instead activate the "Spiralize" option (Cura)/"Vase Mode" (Slic3r) to only print the outermost contour in one continous line. At this point the print will still have a closed bottom rendering it impractical. To fix this set Bottom/Top Wall Thickness to zero. Cura may signal you that this is a dumb idea but trust me it is not. This way you will get an open tube/sleeve that slips right over the solid core providing it with a soft jacket.

Mechanical Postprocessing

After removing the support material some parts were sanded very lightly with P150 and P400 grid.
The EmiterGuard was glued to the Emiter with industrial grade plastics glue befor painting.

The rubber hull of the LowerKnurledChamber has three openings, one for the LowerButton and two for the RedTrigger. Printed in VaseMode/Spiralize they shold be blocked by "indentations" of the outer wall. Take small scissors (e.g. nail clipping ones) and carefully trim them off inside.

Paintjob

Emiter + Guard, OuterGrip, CurveTransition and Pommel were primed, spray painted in high gloss silver and received some highligths in gold emaille paint.
RedTrigger was painted in glossy emaille paint, UpperTrigger in gold and LowerButtonBolt in steel.
Everything else was left as is.

Assembly

For the LowerKnurledChamber, slide the hull over the core in the correct orientation (check openings), then glue in Button and RedTrigger.

For the Grip, first put the rubber hull into the OuterGrip. Align gaps in the knurling with the braces. Then slide in the core completely. The stud/connector of the core should come right through the hole in the OuterGrip. This way no additional Connector is required.

Everything else comes together like in the original version.

Finally put together with plastics glue or cyanoacrylate.

Carefully check the alignment of all parts as all connectors are perfectly round!

NEW

I created the rubber hulls by extracting the knurling from the original parts, leaving only a core minus two times a print wall thickness and some tolerance. This way the elastic hull printed in VaseMode easily fits over the hard plastic core.

For the InnerGrip I even offset the knurling and did a Boolean with the OuterGrip. The resulting body not only slides into the outer grip, like the original one did. It fills the "windows" of the skeleton, improving not only on the feel but also on the look of the whole lightsaber.

IMPROVED

Besides the updated rubber grips I tried to correct some minor flaws with the original files.

First importing one part into my slicer software I immediately noticed some strange artifacts - jagged lines interrupting the top layers (see attached screenshot). Analyzing this further in Blender, I noticed almost every part was rotated around an arbitrary axis by some minor degree. This leads to interrupted layers when slicing/printing. Most certainly this is a precision error in the STL exporter of the CAD software used.

All parts were corrected, realigned and should be oriented for optimal printing results and stability now.

You may wonder why the Emitter is on its tip, seemingly toppling over while the original was resting on its full bottom?! Printing it this way, the decorative, ornamented top will come out perfect in horizontal layers instead of jagged with visible layer lines. And the bottom of the part won't be visible in the final assembly thus can be hideous. Just remember to use sufficient Support Density or even Support Interface so the part won't come off the bed mid print!

Rotation Error on the Pommel

All parts except for the RedTrigger and rubber hulls of course were printed in black mid grade PLA.
The InnerGripHull and LowerKnurledChamberHull are made from black TPE.
RedTrigger is in, well, red PETG.

comments.text: Thanks! I used PlastiKote Brilliant Metallic Silver canned spray paint. Hard to recommend though as it takes forever to dry properly on primed 3D printed parts (grabbing it too firmly may leave fingerprints/marks even after a MONTH of drytime), generally is very prone to scratches and chipping plus cannot be sealed with clear spray paint for protection (solvents will ruin the glossy finish apparently). So as pretty as it might look, I always am quite cautious and hesitant whenever somebody wants to pick this thing up.

description.text: This is a small LED bar used to illuminate the printer work platform from above.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Assembly Notes and Material List.

I used M4 X 12mm long screws and T-nuts to attach the bar to the bottom of the top 20X20mm extrusion of the printer. The screws pass through the assembled LED bar. Be careful at the end where the wires exit, so that you insert the screw between the wires inside the bar without compromising them.

The LED's are wired in parallel, with a series resistor (470 OHMS) on the power feed to them. The 12V power was wired directly to the printers power supply. You could put a switch in the circuit if you want to be able to turn off the LED's.

You will require five 5mm LED's, one 470 ohm resistor, 20ga hookup wire, two 4mm T-nuts, two 4mm washers and two 4M x 12mm screws.

description.text: I designed this mod to make my own concrete pavers. It can be printed with PLA, although I recommend TPU. TPU makes it easier to flex the mold and remove the paver once dry. A 10-20% infill works good.

print_settings.Notes:: I used 3 perimeters.

description.text:
Glue on some sandpaper around the cylinder, leave the ends without sandpaper.

The cylinder gives you 4 sanding options:

description.text:
ITEM T-Nut M3 ( Nut 8 )

This T-Nut M3 for ITEM light profiles was designed for a DIY laser cutter project.

The T-Nut is accurately designed, so that it fits well into the groove, but does not slide down like other T-nuts.
So the stone stays in position and it can easily side parts etc. are mounted.

(+) very precise and form-fitting
(+) No twisting or tilting
(+) high stability if the infill is increased accordingly
(+) T-nuts do not fall down even in a vertical position

(-) fits only ITEM light profiles, otherwise all positive points will get worse

alternative T-nuts:

--> M5 T-Nut: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2771480

--> M4 T-Nut: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2770009

title: QI Wireless Charger for IKEA bed for 5.1" smartphone

description.text:
Here is a self-designed QI wireless charger bed for IKEA bed for 5.1" phones (I'm using it for Samsung Galaxy S6 and S7).

Electronics used for: https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Qi-Wireless-Universal-Charger-PCBA-Circuit-Board-Coil-Wireless-Charging-Micro-USB-Port-DIY/32780560736.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.F7DXEs

Before the final release, I did 3 prototypes. The last one is fixed with screws on back side, but in principle can be used without screws.

Consist of two parts:

  • body: charger_v3_p1.stl
  • and top thin cover: charger_v3_p2.stl

The body is printed lying on side with holes for screws, with supports.

PCB is fixed inside body with two spots of hot-glue.
The coil placed on short pieces of flexible tubes - just to raise a bit and keep touching the top cover - to minimize distance between coil and phone (used pieces of heat shrink tube for that).
The top thin cover is glued with acetone (used ABS for the thing).

Printed 2 of them, for both sides of our bed. The LEDs on PCB are way too bright at night, therefore I used a black insulating tape with pin-holes (see photo). Now LED's light can be seen only on direct sight - doesn't disturb anymore.

Also attaching source of model: designed in FreeCAD. There are a lot of invisible garbage objects, used during designing... may be used if someone would like to adjust for their bed size, or another smartphone size.

title: MP Select Mini Side Panel with 30 mm Cooling Fan and Bed Wires

description.text:
MP Select Mini Side Panel

This side panel for the Monoprice Select Mini/Malyan M200 provides ventilation for the mainboard and allows you to mount a 30 mm cooling fan and reroute the bed wires out the side. I put a 40 mm fan on the hotend so I used the original 30 mm fan from the hotend for this side panel. The cutout for the fan is the Aperture Science logo from Portal.

The fan is attached with #4-40x0.75 in screws and nuts and I placed a dust filter inside between the fan and side panel. I didn't find a 30 mm dust filter, so cut down a larger dust filter with scissors and an X-ACTO knife.

The rubber grommet on the hole for the bed wires is from the bed where the wires used to go through before I moved them.

Links

  • Screws: #4-40x0.75 in screws and nuts
  • Dust Filter: Fan Dust Filter Mesh
  • Tinkercad: MPSM Side Panel Right

Remixed from:

  • Malyan M200 / MP select mini side cooling 60mm/50mm fan
  • Monoprice Select Mini 30 mm Fan Guards

In response to Thingiverse's Capture Your Town challenge, I've captured several locations in Anaheim; "my town", broadly speaking, being Southern California. These are significant locations here right now, for horrible reasons: The first 3D photoscan is of an ephemeral memorial marking the location where Manuel Diaz was shot to death by Anaheim police on July 21, 2012, at 704 North Anna Drive. This memorial is a public display - those signs are there to be read, and to call attention to the physical place where this event happened - but if I had felt even the slightest cue from anyone in the area that I was intruding or unwelcome, I would have left without photographing anything. When I asked permission, a resident of the building waved me into the gated yard so I could photograph the area behind the fence where Diaz died, handcuffed, face down in the grass. As I was photographing, there was a birthday party with children playing in a bouncy house 40 feet away. (You can just barely see it in the next scan.) Eventually this spot will be reclaimed by children at play too; the memorial won't last forever, and this photoscan, crude and ethereal as it is, may prove more permanent. The second photoscan is of the spot about 250 feet away, at the corner of North Anna Drive and La Palma, where the residents who had immediately gathered were backed up against the intersection. Here, a few hours later, the police met them with "less-than-lethal" small arms fire fired directly into the small crowd of unarmed men, women, and children. A police dog was released into the crowd here too. However poorly rendered in my scan, it's a real place. The third photoscan is of Anaheim City Hall, where an overflow City Council meeting spilled into the streets, and where police opened up with more "less-than-lethal" fire on citizens, including credentialed, mainstream media journalists. The fourth photoscan is of the Anaheim Police Department. As I was photographing, a truck cruised by slowly, holding up traffic behind them. Two women leaned out of the truck to shout taunts at the police building. There was raw disgust and contempt in their voices - it'd be hard to describe, other than that they were focused. There were no police in sight - they were shouting at the building and what it symbolizes to them; people vest a lot in "things", as users of this site surely know. Barricades have been erected, police in camouflage military uniforms now stand guard, and news vans wait for chaos. The fifth scan: a church. As I was leaving, trucks pulled into the parking lot of the Iglesia Ni Cristo directly across the street from the police department. Workers began boarding up the church windows in anticipation of what may be coming to this particular corner of "my town". -Cosmo Wenman

All my photos were taken in the afternoon of July 28, 2012. Ideally, the memorial, memorial detail, and street corner meshes would be merged into a single model, as they are nearly contiguous areas. From many news reports, you would think that the residents convened a protest, foolishly bringing their kids along. Instead, seeing how close these places are to each other, you can see that the events came to them, where they live. Unfortunately I was not able to get the software to model these spaces into a single scene. The police department and church should be merged as well, as those are a single space. There are a couple ways to view these crude, unedited (and error-filled) 3D photoscans:

  • If your computer has an OpenGL enabled graphics card, download and install Autodesk's free "123D Catch" application. Then download the ".3dp" files listed at left on this page, and open them in the "Catch" application. You'll be able to pan and zoom in and around the scans from all angles.

  • If you have a 3D editing application, use the Catch program to open the .3dp files, then export .obj files and their associated texture files.

  • I've uploaded a few of my photos, including close-ups of several of the signs at the memorial, which were included in the memorial scan at lower resolution.

  • Or, I've made a short video panning around the rendered scenes here: http://youtu.be/gejvjGY2f9U

    If for whatever reason you wanted to print any of these, the memorial detail of the crucifix may not be too far from print-ready. The others would take a lot of editing.

    More information on why these are significant places worth documenting in any media that might help convey their physicality:

    • Disturbing, anonymous video of the shooting's immediate aftermath, at what is now the memorial site: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RIwjUQYnWMM Disturbing newscast, with video of the street corner mayhem: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VZV3iyMz470 An account from the children who live and play there, right next to the memorial: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5Xe3BmM5fZM City Hall, police, journalists: http://bit.ly/PK1v0B

Tech-related observations:

  • While I was photographing, I met someone who's been walking around the neighborhood for a week, broadcasting a live and semi-live video stream from a DIY rig consisting of a smartphone, a steadycam mount, and 48 hours of continuous-use battery life. He's broadcasting via Ustream under "CrossXbones" here: http://www.ustream.tv/channel/crossxbones

  • Here's someone else - "Timcast" - doing the same thing, broadcasting - untethered - a semi-live telepresence: http://www.ustream.tv/user/Timcast
    Here's Timcast experimenting with a home-brew streaming-video aerial surveillance drone late last year: http://www.ustream.tv/recorded/18980007

  • Seeing all the news vans, with their antenna masts extended thirty feet in the air, it occurred to me that they're probably just a few hundred dollars' worth of equipment upgrades away from being able to broadcast a live 3D map of their locations. Maybe just two webcams on the masts, offset for stereoscopic capture. Two or more stationary vans synchronizing continuous mast-cam feeds could produce a stream that could be sliced and stitched into a detailed, navigable, real-time 3D environment.
    • -Cosmo cosmowenman.com
    twitter.com/CosmoWenman
    [email protected]

title: Garage Door Opener Spring Compression Tool

description.text: The rented house I am living in has a broken garage door opener, and the garage door does not have a handle on the outside for opening it manually. The landlord also would not replace the garage door opener since it isn't on the lease. As such, I purchased my own garage door opener. As I plan to take my garage door opener with me when I move out, I will need to uninstall mine, and reinstall his broken one. Part of the installation process is using this little spring tensioner for the belt drive. The tensioner comes with a pre-compressed spring. To be able to use it again, you must recompress the spring and turn the little metal keeper to keep it compressed. The spring is very stiff and not able to be compressed by hand, so I created this tool to give me the grip need to recompress this spring.

title: Tevo Tornado/Creality CR-10 wheel bearing extractor

description.text:
For extraction of beariong out of the wheel

place things on screw like this:

  • washer
  • extractor body
  • wheel
  • plunger
  • washer
  • nut

Tighten the screw until the bearing falls into the extractor body.

For pressing the bearing into the wheel

place things on screw like this:

  • washer
  • extractor body
  • wheel
  • bearing
  • plunger
  • washer
  • nut

Gently tighten the screw until the bearing hit the limiter inside of the wheel. Then repeat with the other side not forgetting to put between the bearings the brass washer.

If you need wheel model

Here you go: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2773181

author: sccsltd

title: Wicked-1X mini quad frame - true x 200mm

description.text:
This is a fun little project that I have created so I don't loose it every time a brake something on a carbon frame :)). This "Wicked-1X" mini quad frame is created so I (or you) can have more flexibility in design and parts availability in my builds.

I have mainly concentrated on ease of access to components and replacement of parts.

Parts List

Arms

The arms can easily be replaced by removing only one screw, this screw also connects the standoffs to the frame.

Bottom plate

the bottom plate holds everything together, the arms are friction fitted by sliding it to their designated place.

Top plate & Holder plate

The holder plate simply covers the bottom plate and the top plate hold the standoff together and also has a small hole at the back ( :)) ) to attache the antenna, I yet to design a gopro case.

Other then the print's above you will also need:

  • 9 - 10-12mm m3 screws (4 for arms, 4 for stack, 1 for the camera mount)
  • 4 - aluminium standoffs for your stack - make sure it fits your stack
  • 4 - 5-6mm m3 screws for the top plate
  • Zip ties

Assembly

Print out the bottom plate, then print out the arms - at this point make sure that the arms slide in the bottom plate nice and snug.

Next up you need to print out the bottom plate holder, now you can assemble the bottom half. Go ahed and sandwich it all together - slide in the arms on the bottom plate and attache the bottom plate holder.

This is where I recommend you add the internal electronics, once that is done attache the top plate and antenna.

INFO
If your main battery cable comes out at the back you have two holes for a zip tie to hold the cable to the frame located on the bottom plate - this is so when you crash you don't brake of your VBAT pads.

Fusion 360 link - http://a360.co/2Bxtfkp

I would love your feedback and remixes a very welcome :)

title: Futuristic Flying Station Wagon "WagenCorps Oldsmobile AD"

description.text:
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/29qbJ8gM55k

Warning: The following may be a bit confusing.

This car and its manufacturer are completely figments of my imagination. The manufacturer is called "WagenCorps" and is a joint project between Volvo, Subaru and Cadillac (none of which I own) devoted to the resurrection of the Station Wagon, which had gone extinct by the figment-of-my-imagination future which the car comes from. In this future, the auto industry is mainly devoted to the manufacture of flying cars known as "Air-Drivers", abbreviated to AD in model names. All of my futuristic car models come from this future. Annotated image of marque symbol is enclosed.

This model is named "Oldsmobile" in the tradition of naming car models after old, obscure or otherwise-discontinued automakers in the futuristic facet from which this whole futuristic-car business stems. The WagenCorps Oldsmobile matches minivans in size and might be mistaken for one if it wasn't common knowledge (in the future that this comes from) that all WagenCorps models are station wagons.

         For practicality's sake, the real model would have weirdly-shaped doors and bucket seats in the first two rows to allow access to the center bench seat, a feature carried from minivans.

If you ever decide to cosplay Geralt, you may have trouble locating correctly sized buckles for the various parts of his attire.

In this set are models of the 50mm, 32mm, and 16mm buckles that are required for the Wolven Armour set.

The 50mm goes on the large belt around the upper body, the 32mm on the armour under the armpits and around the upper arms in the Superior and Mastercrafted versions, and the 16mm go up the front of the tunic and on the little bag that hangs on the front.

Also provided are the tips for the 16mm which attach to the front of the tunic.

Due to the fact that these are 3D printed, I suggest not actually requiring these for load bearing, and simply using them for aesthetic effect. That being said I also recommend printing at 100% infill to maximise strength.

author: thatdude902

description.text: Citrus press (Zitronenpresse)

This is one of my first purely sculptural pieces, inspired by an ostrich egg that I acquired about 20 years ago.
To duplicate this effort you'll need a real ostrich egg, (though I have included one as an .stl just in case.)
You will also need some liquid latex and some sand.
Egg, sand and latex can be found on Amazon.

I have included a base to keep the egg from rolling around. it is not fancy, only functional.
I recommend looking into some of the beautiful candle holders by other Thingiverse artists for a stand of your own. Just remember, the eggs are not perfectly cylindrical so you'll probably need to modify the top of the holder just a bit to keep the egg stable.

HOW I DID IT:
First (if using the real ostrich egg -if not skip to the end) I poured a small amount of liquid latex into the ostrich egg through the hole used to drain the egg.
I then turned the egg thoroughly to ensure the latex coverd the entire surface of the inside of the egg, then allowed it to dry. I needed to repeat this step a few times.
The goal was to achieve an approximate 1-2 mm skin on the inside surface of the egg.
Then with an awl I carefully chipped out a hole large enough for some small nippers which I then used to make a hole large enough for the dragon to emerge from.
I was careful to leave the latex as intact as possible.
I put a few strategically placed cuts in the latex to give the appearance the hatchling was tearing through.

END: I filled the egg with sand, placed the stakes in the pieces, and pushed them into the sand.
This kept the three separate parts from shifting around.

P.S. not shown in the image yet, I plan to heavily polyurethane each piece to give the final model a wet drippy look. Maybe I'll post a new pic later...

comments.text: I had a thought about the egg, if it was split in half with hole facing up it probably would be a lot easier to print on a FDM printer,  maybe add two indexing points for alignment, and too add a bit of gluing surfaces , Gess, I don't know why I didn't think of that last night,  when I started the egg print! So for its a 9 hour print @ 68% (EDIT: 10h.39m) its originally size, that's the only way I could get it to fit my limited SLA print bed. hell here an idea for you ! Split all the Files and repost as a new thing with easy to print title in there so if it would get more attention, it really is a nice model.

title: Base Five, Abacus, Soroban, そろばん, Suan Pan, 算盘

description.text:
Base Five is a worthwhile number system to play with: to understand how positional number systems work and to explore alternative number representations (called numerals in a strict sense). In computer science, bases 2, 8, 16 are definitely required. In K-12 education, base five has pedagogical values. One could make an addition or multiplication table just to see how things work.

As expected, in a base five system, we need five symbols: 0, 1, 2, 3, 4. The base five abacus can be used for base five representations and operations or just as a math toy!

description.text: This is a spool holder to hold spools in a dehumidifier while printing. This is very useful if printing nylon or polycarbonate since they soak up water very quickly and will then print like crap. This holder is inspired by a couple other similar holder designs. The one that was the biggest inspiration was https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2412734. My design uses a larger 6" lazy susan swivel because that is what my local Lowes had.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

15 to 20%

Notes:

Use ABS or any material able to take the 70C (160F) dehumidifier temps without softening too much. PLA & PETG will not work.

You will need to flip over the spindle part to print without supports.

The base part bolts onto one side of the swivel with ~#10 screws (~5mm). I found that extra length on the screws was useful for hooking into the grill on the dryer. For the top portion use ~ m3 or m4 hardware but keep the screws short so they don't stick up too high. 6mm to 8mm is ok. If your screws are a little longer it shouldn't be a big problem. Your spool will just be sitting on the screws.

On the dehydrator I cut out a few trays, drilled a 7/32 hole in the side of one and glued them together with the hole height ~ centered on the spool. Through the hole I inserted some polyethylene tubing with an inside of .170" and an outside diameter of 1/4". This was inserted into the slightly smaller hole I drilled which holds it very securely. The tubing then runs to the printer.

remixed_from.author: dugzmodels
remixed_from.title: 1_72 Remix M3 Lee with Grant turret

description.text:
This is a 28mm scale model of the WW2 Canadian RAM Kangaroo APC.

The source of the RAM was a 1/200 model from m_bergman's great treasure. The separate track is sources from dougzmodels' excellent 1/72nd scale M-3 Lee.

The RAM tank was a medium tank designed and built in Canada during the dark days of 1941-1942. The British had their hands full and the Americans were just gearing up for war. Canada, having never built a tank before, jumped in and developed the RAM tank. It's suspension was a copy of the M-3 Lee suspension but its hull allowed for a fully rotating turret, initially armed with a 2 pounder and later a 6 pounder ATG. Early models also had a small MG turret on the left front hull.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ram_tank

The Canadians shipped these to equip its troops in the UK, but just prior to the invasion of France the Cdn. troopers switched out from their RAMs to the standard allied M4 Sherman.

As the liberation of Europe proceeded, the heavy casualties in the infantry sparked the initiative to employ the surplus RAM tanks as APCs. Many were so converted and were used by both the Canadian and British armies until the end of the war in Europe,

This model started with the 1/200th scale model of the RAM kangaroo from the Bergman files. I cut the tracks off to allow for a cleaner print of the hull. I took the tracks from Dougzmodels and clipped it a bit to fit the front mudguards on the RAM.

Please refer to the photo where gluing the tracks on. there is a slightly higher gap between the hull and the track at the rear than the front. You can see this in the historical pics. I used a bit of a wood match to give me the gap at the back, and a thinner bit of scrap at the front. I used two part plastic epoxy to glue the track on; you can use CA glue but you want to make sure you fit them right the first time, as CA doesn't allow for much repositioning.

The Kangaroo is listed in the British army book.

I loaded two files for the MG turret; one with a gun and a second w/o in case you want to use a piece of metal instead.

title: Laser mounting bracket (OEM-style) for NEJE desktop USB laser engraver (and other brands)

description.text:
Reproduction of the original bracket used to connect the laser to the X-carriage on desktop USB laser engravers branded as NEJE and may others.

Only tested with the 1000mW laser model, but from the pictures I have see it will work with most lasers with two M3 screw holes and most engravers that use the same CD/DVD/BluRay steppers that attach with in a "four peg" style.

Depending on how much "squish" your first layer has, you may need to clean out the screw and mounting holes with a small knife.

title: FPV combo - case for CCD board cam & 5.8GHz Tx

description.text:
I liked very much the idea of Octovir project: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:139423 so I decided to redrawn it and add something new from me.

In short - this is standalone FPV kit which requires only some power to work (7-24V) and you can simply mount it in different vehicles/planes/copters - because of different mounting parts (-25°, 90°, 120° and gopro style) It's very flexible to use.

There are many combinations:

  • minimalist: camera_case_1 + camera_case_2
  • gopro: camera_case_1 + camera_case_2 + camera_case_4 + camera_case_3_gopro_mount_ver2
  • racing: camera_case_1 + camera_case_2 + camera_case_4 + camera_case3-25d
    etc,....

Part list:

  • 4xM3 screws; length depends on the selected version
  • Eachine TX526 5.8G 40CH 25MW/200MW/600MW Switchable AV Wireless FPV Transmitter https://www.banggood.com/Eachine-TX526-5_8G-40CH-25MW200MW600MW-Switchable-AV-Wireless-FPV-Transmitter-RP-SMA-Female-p-1083642.html

print_settings.Notes:: You will also need a 0.125" diameter steel shaft (available from most hardware stores) that is 2.465" long, and also 48 US pennies, preferably new.

description.text:
This is my take on the venerable Dyna Bee gyroscopic exercise ball that came out in the late 1970's. It uses 48 pennies (US) as the flywheel mass. As a twist, I've added a geared zip starter to get the rotor spinning up to speed. From there, you keep it going with pure wrist power.

Aside from the 3D printed parts, you will need a 0.125" diameter steel rod and some superglue to put it together.

UPDATE: I've modified the shell to make it easier to align the zip starter with the slots in the side.

https://youtu.be/PxPEBXRKOyI

Printer:

UDIO

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Print to two of the shell.STL, two of the rotor.STL, one of the ring.STL and one of the gear.STL. I've included two versions of the rack.STL (the zip starter) - one about 11" long and a shorter one about 7.5" long that should fit on a 250x250mm print bed.

You will also need a 0.125" diameter steel shaft (available from most hardware stores) that is 2.465" long, and also 48 US pennies, preferably new.

Assembly
  1. After printing, sand the top and bottom surfaces of the ring smooth. Also sand smooth the the surface of the shell that the ring rubs against.
  2. Insert 6 US pennies into each cavity of both rotors (48 total). Use pennies all of the same type because different versions (with different back designs) have slightly different weights. Use a few drops of superglue to hold the pennies in place.
  3. Insert your 0.125" diameter steel shaft into one of the rotor halves and position it so that it sticks out of the bottom side by exactly 0.750". Superglue the shaft in place.
  4. Slide the gear over the other end of the shaft and superglue it in place too.
  5. Slide the other rotor half over the shaft and superglue it to the gear, too.
  6. Place the ring in one of the shell halves, and then place the rotor assembly such that the ends of the shaft fit into the notches in the ring.
  7. Assemble the other shell half to the bottom half. If you are lucky the two will fit together with a satisfying click and will stay together. If the fit is a little loose, Temporarily tape the two shell halves together until you know that everything works properly. Once you are sure it all works, you can glue the two shell halves together.
Use

The only real annoying thing with this design is that you have to align the rotor so that the gap in the center with the gear lines up with one of the zip starter slots in the top or bottom shell. You can use the tip of the zip starter to poke through one of the slots to rotate the rotor and ring into place.

Once aligned, insert the zip starter, teeth towards the center of the ball, into the slot - it should engage the central gear. Shove the starter all the way in and then pull it back out smartly. This should give you enough speed to start accelerating the rotor using a wrist wobbling motion. Check out this video to see it in use: https://youtu.be/0vgsZctOkaI

comments.text: Awesome.  How well does this thing work?
comments.author: universaljoint

comments.text: Surprisingly well.  I had one of the original Dyna Bees back in the late '70's and it was a pain to get started.  This design uses a 3.2mm dia shaft whereas the original Dyna Bee had a 2.5mm shaft.  The larger shaft diameter (plus the zip starter) makes it easier to start it and keep it running.  The downside, though, is that you can't get it up to quite as high a speed.  I'm thinking of creating a second version that uses a smaller diameter shaft to see how well that works.
comments.author: universaljoint

comments.text: I have one of the light up ones and was always amazed by the speed it could reach.  Good for you for trying this out.  I love all your designs by the way.  Equal parts technically impressive and insanely creative.

comments.text: Hey, thanks!  If you print one of these, let me know how it works out.

I used this adapter for the RC Speed Tank by Bryant87. It is an adapter for 3.125mm to 5mm axles. To print it I recommend to start with default settings and increase/decrease flow depending on how well it fits (optimally it wouldn't have any noticeable play). There are three versions, but I recommend using the adapter_hole version, as I used it successfully.
Regarding the stability it seems to be very good, as my speed tank uses pretty strong motors and I never had a problem with these printed of PLA.
The material doesn't really matter, but be aware of shrinkage for materials like abs.

title: Ikea Lack Squash Ball Dampener / Anti Vibration Feet
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These inserts for Ikea Lack series tables cancel coupled noise from your 3D-Printer or other devices positioned on the table.

I had to go this step as the Y-axis of my prusa clone is pretty noisy and can easily be heard in the flat beyond me, coupling through the wooden ceiling.

Each leg of the table is sawn in half about 20cm from its top and the dampener is inserted.
They should be friction fit, but can also be glued in place.

Alternatively you should be able to remove the bottom plate of each leg and insert a single holder part with a ball fitted to the lowest table. Not tested yet, but the dimensions look okay.

For each leg you will need one 90° and one 45°-version.

Which one you insert where is up to you.

A standard squash ball is squished between them and both halfs of the dampener module are then combined.
Should be self-explanatory ;)

I used blue (fast) squash balls for mine, which ball you use depends on your needs:
The softer the balls, the greater dampening should be, but softer balls also do not support that much weight without deforming.

To stiffen the lower part of the leg (which is free to move in two axis because of the ball-joint now) i added a part to fix it to the top of another Lack-table.
This part should be printed with the mounting plate down, using support!

Enjoy!

Updates:
2018-02-04 - Updated version of the insert part, fits better now and won't crack the glued edges of the legs, Added a part for fixing the lower leg part to the table beyond.
2018-02-10 - Added stacker feet with inlayed screws

title: New 3DS XL hand grip - remix
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a remix of the fantastic grip created by zeroordie881. Upon printing that one, I found that the fit was a tad loose from top to bottom and the power button hole didn't quite line up with the actual button. The problem with the loose fit turned out to be because the two small tabs at the top that are supposed to slip into the holes on the rear of the 3ds kept breaking off with the support material. I tried bumps instead, but those too kept breaking off, so I finally just dropped the large tabs down 1mm. Perfect snug fit!

I didn't want to do a remix just for such a minor modification, so I added a slot to allow for accessing the game cartridge slot. I also cut a slot along the edge above the power button so that all of the indicator LEDs can be more easily seen, even with the 3ds closed.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

90%

Notes:

Print in the same orientation as the original, which is reflected already in this model. For smaller, 200x200mm beds, you will need to arrange the model diagonally on the bed for it to fit.

comments.text: Fits decently but not perfectly. The bottom edge pops up so the whole thing is loose; if I turned it over it would fall out. Would like to see a fix for this, so the bottom stays seated all the way down.
comments.author: dduberman

comments.text: Unfortunately, there isn't much to work with as far as where to grip the 3ds  goes that will still allow the top to close. I'd be happy t o upload the source file tonight if you'd like to give it a try. Alternatively, you might could consider a couple of small strips of velcro to help keep the game in the grip. Secure the fuzzy pieces to the bottom of the 3ds and the hook pieces to the grip.
comments.author: dduberman

comments.text: Thanks. Actually, I discovered and removed a few stray pieces of support material where the looseness was, and the fit is better now, albeit not perfect. I wonder if just applying some masking or electrical tape would improve it. I'll try that.

description.text:
I created this Living colors look-a-like RGB light to add some mood lighting to my living room.
Powered by a ESP8266 (NodeMCU V3) and a WS2812B led ring.

I used Github project DIYhue to control the lights with the Hue app and my Domoticz system.

  • 84 mm ws2812b led ring : Link
  • NodeMCU : Link
  • Software project (by github user mariusmotea) : Link

The DataIN on the WS2812b is connected to the RX on the NodeMCU.

I created this round shape and separate "stand" to swivel the light to a position and angle that you want.

The two holes on the body can be drilled to 2.5MM and cut some M3 threads into the mounts to allow the mounting of the top part.

The NodeMCU mounting case can be placed into the body with some double sided tape.

For the Power cable just drill a hole in the body to accommodate the cable.

Outer pieces should snap together tightly with an interference fit, but may vary depending on printer settings and materials used. description.text: Snake-like bendy toy with a satisfying click. My attempt to recreate a physical object from my own childhood which brings back the memories that I have associated with it.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

To make the design here, print 16x of the outer pieces (print half of these in a contrasting color if desired) and 7x of the inner pieces. Outer pieces should snap together tightly with an interference fit, but may vary depending on printer settings and materials used. I'm imagining glue and or a drill bit may be helpful if the fit isn't quite right.

This is is the result of about a day of iterations trying to get the right feel dialed in. Quite functional when I printed it in PLA, which is easy to find and print with. Probably not the ideal plastic for this sort of toy though, a little more give would work better. To make it usable I've tried to take advantage of the flexibility of thinner parts printed in PLA, but it may be better to use a softer, slightly more flexible plastic for the inner pieces (not as much as flex filament, but nylon perhaps?)

The inner piece is the first thing I've designed with significant bridging, but the printer worked a champ. All of the ones I attempted to print came out fine.

comments.text: I printed all 16, incl. the 7 connector. But they don't fit. I managed to break 2 pins on just trying to click them together. Too bad. Nice idea, but needs more work. The pins are too thin to sand,file.

author: jewzaam

title: 40mm Air Filter w/ Stackable Carbon Cartridge

description.text:
This is a quick and simple design, somewhat low profile, that I made for my Lack enclosure. I think it is pretty universal though. If you have a case, just cut a hole and it will work.

Two simple features that I focused on:

  1. Stackable cartridges gives you the option to add more activated carbon to further reduce the odor. If your wife still complaining about the ABS odor then just add more cartridges!
  2. The fins on the cartridge provides an even mixed of filtered and unfiltered air to optimize the filtering quality of the next layer of carbon cartridge. Also serves as spacer for air flow and not putting too much load on the fan.

0-10% Infil. I don't think infill is needed because it is only a container after all.
Support only when printing Stackable Cartridge for nice square connecting lips.
Parts are snap-on and firm-fit. only need 2 screws for the fan.

Feel free to tinker with this. If you made it better in anyway, I would love to use it!

author: flufflicks

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/enwMDMDGYLR

This is a WIP. The goal is to have a set of parts that can be used to build an airboat, which is basically just a motor mount, a servo mount and a rudder mechanism. I will add the parts to this thing as I model and print them.

I designed the motor mount for an Emax CF-2822 and a 10x5 propeller which is what I had, so any motor that uses the same 22mm diameter mounting holes and any propeller smaller than a 10x5 should fit.

I'm using 3/8" aluminum tubing as a structural element because it was free (it was found in a garbage pile on the sidewalk), but it should be cheap and easy to find. I also use 3x5x5 brass inserts for M3 screws. I will use M5 screws for now, but I may change this in the future so that every screw is a M3 and the brass inserts are captive nuts instead.

The rudder mount is two pieces of the same aluminum tubing. Rudder blades will have to be cut from depron or any other sheet-like material, which will then be attached to printed parts which will also have control horns.

Servo linkages will be just a few pieces of nylon string in a pull-pull configuration.
Keychain, scaled 75% is a nice, usable size.

I'd recommend a minimum of 3 layers for perimeter, top. and bottom. I printed at 0.2/layer with a 0.4 nozzle and I used 10 layers for bottom and 4 layers for side and top. Probably overkill but I prefer overkill to it breaking when full. If you print in ABS, PETG, or with a larger nozzle you can probably reduce quite a bit. Of course you may need to scale a bit if printing in something other than PLA or if your printer is calibrated better/worse than mine..

description.text: I like my 40oz stainless cup but it's a bit of a literal handful. The walls didn't have enough taper for a simple loop style handle like the ones for the 30 oz cups though. My solution was to support from the lower taper. The cutouts on the side reduce filament cost and help with 'gripability'. I feel like I should probably get around to making a thinner/lighter version without the handle because the extra texture of just the sleeve with the window cutouts greatly helps with handling.

Creality CR10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Orient so the flat side on the top of the handle sits on the bed. Infill shouldn't be necessary but I used 20% for my print. I'd recommend a minimum of 3 layers for perimeter, top. and bottom. I printed at 0.2/layer with a 0.4 nozzle and I used 10 layers for bottom and 4 layers for side and top. Probably overkill but I prefer overkill to it breaking when full. If you print in ABS, PETG, or with a larger nozzle you can probably reduce quite a bit. Of course you may need to scale a bit if printing in something other than PLA or if your printer is calibrated better/worse than mine..

My print came out very slightly oversized. Not sure if my measurements were off or my printer is slightly out of calibration but oversize is easier to fix than too small. I heated the finished part in the oven at 180* for 20 minutes then slipped it over the mug while still hot and flexible and it shrank to a perfect fit. Unfortunately it's probably never coming off without cutting it off now so I can't recommend this step if you want to keep the cup dishwasher safe.

title: On/Off Button mount for Makerselect v2/wanhao duplicator.

description.text:
I have my monoprice Maker select v2 printer connected via a relay as described in thing 1428478 so I can turn it on and off remotely from octoprint. This is great, but I wanted a local way to turn it on or off without having to use a browser or the power switch. Turning it off via the power switch means that it can't be turned back on via octoprint, and turning it off via octoprint means it can't be turned back on with the power switch.

So I designed the button mount to attach a push button switch to the side of the printer. The button is wired to the raspberry pi to provide another input that can be used to trigger a script to toggle the printer state.

It screws into the two screws near the top on the right side. You will need two (2) M3 screws at least 8mm long to replace the short screws. I used 10mm screws left over from the z-brace mod. You will also need a push button with a shaft no wider than 16mm and a collar/nut between 16mm and 25mm. I pulled my button from my collection, but it was like this one from adafruit.

Those two screws hold the top brace in place, so I would take care to never remove them both at once.

Installation instructions

  1. Solder two wires to the switch.
  2. Measure and cut wires to desired length, adding an inch or two for routing via the channel in the bottom of the button holder.
  3. Thread button switch into large hole on button holder, and secure with the nut that comes with the switch.
  4. Unscrew the top screw from the printer.
  5. Secure the top of the holder to the printer using a longer M3 screw to replace the one you took out. Tighten it enough to secure the printer, but still let the button holder swivel.
  6. Remove the second short screw.
  7. Route the wires in the channel on the button holder and swivel the holder until the bottom hole lines up.
  8. Screw the second longer screw to the bottom hole.
  9. Making sure that the wires are coming out of the channel and are not pinched, tighten down both screws.
  10. Connect other end of the wires to your Raspberry pi or whatever the switch is going to control. I used Pin 26 and Ground

software setup

I already had scripts to start or stop the printer by toggling pin 19 of the raspberry pi which was connected to the relay, as described in jeffeb3's thing 1428478. Now I needed to read the pin I wired up (pin 26, paradoxically right by pin 19) and toggle the printer state. Here is how I did it, adjust these steps to match your setup:

I made the following script to read pin 19 and toogle the power state. It runs the same scripts that octoprint does to power the printer on or off. That way if I choose to change the behavior of one of them, the toggle script will pick up the change.

#!/bin/bash
state=`gpio -g read 19`
echo "state is $state"
if [ "$state" -eq "0" ]
then
   /home/pi/scripts/printer_on.sh
   echo "turning printer on"
else
   /home/pi/scripts/printer_off.sh
   echo "turning printer off"
fi

Once I had verified that this worked, I had to trigger it whenever the button shorts the button pin (26 in my case) to ground.

  1. Configure the pin to be input -- gpio export 26 in
  2. Configure the internal pullup resistor, so it reads 1 when the button is NOT pressed -- gpio mode 26 up
  3. Test to see if the button works by reading the pin with the button pressed and not pressed -- gpio read 26

To watch the pin I downloaded and compiled gpio-watch program. gpio-watch has a mode where it will watch for a rising edge (transition from 0 to 1) and "debounce" the signal by waiting to see if the signal stays the same before showing the change. This is to keep the button from triggering multiple times during the transition between the switch being fully engaged and disengaged. The debounce time the software is compiled with was inadequate on my raspberry pi 3, I had to increase it several times before it reliably triggered only once per button press.

  1. dowload the zip file and expand it
  2. Edit "main.c" and change the line that says #define DEBOUNCE_INTERVAL 100000L to #define DEBOUNCE_INTERVAL 100000000L (or whatever value works for you).
  3. Compile the software -- make
  4. install it -- sudo make install

After gpio-watch is configured to watch a pin, it will run a script with the same name as a pin in /etc/gpio-watch. So in my case, it runs /etc/gpio-watch/26.

#!/bin/sh
#echo "Something happened! Pin=$1, value=$2"
/home/pi/scripts/printer_toggle.sh

After that script is in place, you can test it with gpio-watch 26:switch. Note that this will only work if you have configured the pin as detailed above.

Finally, you have to set the pi to set up the pins at startup and to run the gpio-watch process in the background. Add this to rc.local:

/usr/bin/gpio export 26 in
/usr/bin/gpio mode 26 up
/usr/bin/gpio-watch 26:switch &

Now enjoy turning your printer on and off with the press of a button, while still being able to control it from octoprint.

title: Light Pipe Adapter for Raspberry Pi 3 Model B

description.text:
This is an adapter designed to move the Raspberry Pi Model 3B LEDs to a front panel when integrating it in an enclosure.

It fits highly affordable 1mm diameter PMMA light pipes (sometimes also called fiber optics), and provides a reasonably bright display at the far end. The main use is to see if the SD card is active when powering the Pi down with a soft power switch before cutting the main power.

A small panel mount light pipe adapter is also included with a matching nut. Thread type is 1/4" ACME since it's very easy to print. It will fit in a 6 mm hole if your drill is sloppy.

After printing, ream the holes with a 1-1.1mm drill to clear out printing gunk. After pushing the pipe through, I suggest grinding the ends flat. That improves light coupling and significantly improves the look of the exterior end since it's more omnidirectional.
The easiest way to do it is to use a dremel with the standard drum-sander accessory at 10k rpm or more.
Since the end is often widened a bit from this process it's best to do it after pushing it through the printed adapter.
(Some Loctite 401 super glue at the end works well for retention), hot glue can be used but it will melt the light pipe slightly (this also makes it very easy to bend).
Update Super glue makes the PMMA pipe extremely brittle so I suggest avoiding it. Hot glue, silicone or just relying on the friction fit should be fine.

The ID of the mounting hole is 3mm to clear the 2.5mm hole of the Pi; the height is 5 mm so you'll need a longer screw than normal (M2.5x10 should be fine with a 6mm hex spacer).

print_settings.Notes:: I strongly suggest using PETG because of its flexibility and strong layer bonds. Also, since the outside of the mug can sometimes get hot when being microwaved, petg will handle that way better than PLA.  Printing one perimeter thick witth low infill will give a corrugated effect that will provide cushioning.  Also makes for a neat visual effect if you use a translucent material!

description.text:
I use these ceramic mugs for lunch at work because i don't like heating my food up in plastic containers. But, I've managed to damage a couple of them over time by impacting the mugs in various ways. One completely shattered when I clumsily clanked it into a granite counter. This protects from these kinds of impacts.

Recently I accidentally did about a 2 foot drop test on a concrete floor with this protector. The mug bounced, but amazingly there was no damage! I am sure a little luck was involved, but there is no way it would have survived without this.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

~10%

Notes:

I printed mine with PETG with just one perimeter and 10% infill. My layers were .3mm and i used 4 top and bottom layers. I cranked up my extrusion factor about 8% for good measure to make sure the single perimeters were a little extra thick. With a 50mm/s print speed it took about 4.5 hours.

I strongly suggest using PETG because of its flexibility and strong layer bonds. Also, since the outside of the mug can sometimes get hot when being microwaved, petg will handle that way better than PLA. Printing one perimeter thick witth low infill will give a corrugated effect that will provide cushioning. Also makes for a neat visual effect if you use a translucent material!

It is designed to be a little tight. The first time you put the mug in, it probably won't rest fully on the bottom without a bit of pressure. You can either soften the plastic a little with a heat gun or hot water and then put the mug in to get that perfect fit - or you could just use it and after a couple trips through the microwave with a warm mug, it will eventually conform perfectly.

print_settings.Notes:: One of the 5015 brackets requires support for a couple of inset screw holes.

title: Tevo Tornado Fang Fan Shroud for 40mm and 5015 fans with BL-touch mount.

description.text:
Fang Replacement Fan shroud for stock Tevo Tornado hot end. It's an evolution of the first Fang shroud I made that uses two 40mm fans. You can check that one out here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2756527

Printing:

  • I printed mine at 0.3mm layer height with 15% infill at 60mm/s. The shroud was printed with supports disabled and the rest of the pieces with supports(one of the brackets needs supports for a couple of inset screw holes).
  • I printed in eSUN PLA+, but regular PLA should do the job just fine as well.

Assembling:

  • Be careful when sliding the blower brackets into place as applying excessive force may cause them to break. Learned that the hard way.
  • Once the 5015 fan is installed, the brackets feel pretty sturdy thanks to the rigidity provided by the body of the fan.
  • You can superglue the 5015 fan brackets if you want, but It's not necessary. I didn't glue mine and it holds up just fine.
  • As far as fasteners go, I used machine screws and just pre-tap the holes with one of the screws before mounting the fans.

Hardware:

  • Original shroud screws(x2)
  • x4 M3x12 screws or other self-tapping screws that fit the mounting holes for the 40mm fan.
  • x2 M3x20 screw to mount the 5015 blower fan.
  • x1 M3x8 screw for mounting hole where BL-touch mount overlaps Fang mounting leg.

Fans:

  • I'd previously converted all my fans to 12V fans using a step-down regulator to power them.
  • x1 40mm fan for hotend ( stock one may be used, but I went with a Noctua NF-A4x10 FLX)
  • x1 5015 blower fan (I got mine from Amazon: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B071WMHNG5/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1)

Testing:

  • I printed the 150mm bridging test found here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2754688
  • It did well in my opinion. Not perfect, but you can judge from the picture.

The Bad:

  • If you have the frame brace mod on your Tornado, you will loose some height because of the blower fan sticking up.

Printer:

Tevo Tornado

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

The fang shroud requires no support if you have decent part cooling.

One of the 5015 brackets requires support for a couple of inset screw holes.

title: Y-Axis Belt Tensioner for Original Prusa MK2, MK2S

description.text:
I wasn't satisfied with rotating the motor to tension the Y-Axis. Of everything I looked at or considered, this seems like the best solution. I remixed this model, making the opending wider to fit the belt pulley for my MK2S.

I used an extra bolt that came with my machine. That works but a hex (not allen) bolt would be easier to work within the tight proximity to the front LCD screen on the MK2 Printer.

This is a model of the color palette in Tinkercad, so that you can test how various TInkercad colors will look when printed on an ink-based full color 3D printer such as the XYZ da Vinci Color.

If you want to print your color designs in Full Color Sandstone at Shapeways, then you might also be interested in the Tinkercad Color Palette model in our geekhaus shop.

For more information about this model and about 3D printing in color, check out our article Multicolor 3D Printing, from Tinkercad to XYZ on Hacktastic.

title: Fallout Magnetic Tiles (2017 Board Game) by Fantasy Flight Games

description.text:
Magnetic tiles for the Fallout board game by Fantasy Flight Games.

It uses 5mm spherical magnets (2 per side; 12 per tile) to lock any tile to another in any orientation.

To assemble a tile place the tile face down and put a magnet in each of the large holes. Once the tile has been filed use superglue to secure the tile plate to the tile. Be careful not to get glue on the magnets as that will prevent them from moving when brought near other magnets ruining its ability to attract any side of any tile.

Note: There are 2 pegs on the tile plate that align to 2 guide holes on the tile to ensure a proper fit when gluing.

Printer:

DeltaMaker V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

15%-20%

Notes:

I printed my tile with supports to ensure that there were no problems with the holes for the magnets. You may or may not need the supports depending on your printer.

comments.author: indianajo883

comments.text: The tiles are held snugly by the frames so you can flip them without worrying about them falling out.  How easy it is to separate the tiles depends on the strength of the magnets used.

print_settings.Notes:: I used ABS for its stability. I think you could get away with PLA because it is pretty robust but I expect it would degrade over time.

description.text:
designed this for my new (and far more stable print bed) I have been tinkering with this thing for a few weeks now. the frame is machined aluminum and has drilled and tapped holes for all of the mounts, the end stops are integrated into the rail mounts with tapped m3 screw holes (see rail guide mount set in my designs) I haven't put the belt back on yet simply because I still have 2 slots to mill so I can mount my uprights that hold my z axis square to the print bed. When all is said and done the z-axis should be square to the bed within .01 mm or that is what my plan calls for. If anyone wants plans and prints for the upgraded bed frame etc. I can provide them upon request so you can make your own. Any other questions feel free to ask. I look forward to sharing the final product with you all.

*Pulley mount to follow in the next day or 2

author: dbcoop

description.text:
I saw this cool Spherical Burr Puzzle design by trinityscsp (https://grabcad.com/trinityscsp) at GrabCAD (https://grabcad.com/library/wheel-puzzle-wooden-toy-1) and wanted to print it.

The problem was that the original CAD files contained perfect geometry and had no slack for the parts to move. In order to make it printable I applied a negative surface displace of 0.2mm to every part using Blender.

The prints in the photos are in PLA with 0.3mm quality and 20% infill. The pieces fit and slide well, and the puzzle holds together properly once finished.

Enjoy and give all the credit to trinityscsp!

This was designed to house a raspberry pi I was using as a media computer. There are two parts - the base tower and the pi case. The pi case holds the pi and is positioned at an angle in the tower so that the video, audio, and power jacks are inside the tower. The back of the tower is open for those cables to come out the back.
I designed this for a square button or switch to mount in the tower to control the power. The SD card and USB ports are also easily acceptable.
Designed for the 'B' shape of Pi (2/3).

I made this bracket because all the brackets I find on the www places the sensor either in front of or behind the print nozzle.
This does not work for me since I attach my glass plate with bulldog clips, for example; if the sensor is +40 in front of the print nozzle it crashes with the bulldog clips..

This bracket has an y offset at 0 so it will never move farther ahead or behind the print nozzle :-)

No crashing with the bulldog clips :-)

I use two M2.5x20 screws, and four nuts to secure the sensor.
Use the BLTouch_83_Spacer.stl to adjust the correct height.

Offsets for this sensor bracket:

X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER +60
Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0

The boundaries for probing (where the probe can reach).
LEFT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 27
RIGHT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 195
FRONT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 20
BACK_PROBE_BED_POSITION 190

title: Aluminium Prusa i3 Filament Guide and tangle prevention

description.text:
New filament reels are filled all the way to the edges with no extra borders to keep the filament on the reel. A lot of my prints got tangles and aborted due to filament coming off the reel and getting tangled.

So I designed a reel guard and filament guide all in one, all adjustable for different width of the reels using the bolts and nuts which are used to assemble eSun filament reels. So at least you won't have to run to the store looking for bolts and nuts.

This was designed for Aluminum Geetech Prusa i3 frame which has 6mm thickness and should sit on top of the frame under the reel if display is removed and relocated to a different place. So if you have Geetech Aluminum Prusa, this mod is for you.

Enjoy printing, don't forget to like if you find it useful.

remixed_from.author: counterstrikegamer44
remixed_from.title: Nerf Rival Apollo Pump Conversion and stock

description.text: This is a raised picatinny rail for use with counterstrikergamer44's pump conversion kit - allows for mounting a sight, etc

This is a remix of wkarraker's nice BB-8 and uses his BB-8 body design as a foundation for bB-8's nemesis, BB-9E. This is a work in progress and I will be adding the other pieces as I complete the design and test fit the parts..

Printing Instructions:

Printed using Monoprice Select Mini V1 - I used a combination of .0875 and .175 layer heights. These are multiples of the "magic numbers" for the stock MP Select Mini. I will note what layer height was used for each piece. I used a top and bottom thickness of 1.2 and sides of 1.2. In general I used 10% infill and 50mms for travel speed, except as noted.

BB-9E_Head_New.stl - Print one copy. I used a combination of Black and Silver PLA. I printed the head at .0875 layer height, 35 mms & 10% infill. I edited the GCODE to add an M600 command at layers 8, 16, 205, 225, 236 and 242. I started using black PLA and when the pauses occured, alternated between silver and black. If your printer is tuned in well, this will result in a much cleaner line than could be obtained with paint.

BB-9E_Head_Eye.stl - Print one copy. I used black and silver PLA. I used .0875 layer height, 25mms and 100% infill. Edit the GCODE to add an M600 command at layer 24. Start with black and switch to silver at the pause.

BB-9E_Head_Bottom.stl - Print one copy. I used black PLA at .0875 layer height, 10% infill, 35mms.

BB-9E_Head_Bottom_Ring.stl - Print one copy. I sued silver PLA at .0875 layer height, 10% infill and 35mms.

BB-9E_Head_Blue_Lens.stl - Print one copy. I used sme translucent blue PLA and printed at .0875 layer height, 100% infill and 25mms.

Edit 1: I've added BB-9E's body ball. There are holes inside the body to accept 8mm x 3mm magnets. I used a dot of super glue to hold the magnets at the bottom of the hole. Make sure you align the magnets in the proper pole orientation to match the other magnets in the body so the head will attach to the body. I used the following magnets for this part of the project: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01MZ6EJE2

Edit 2: I've added the two pieces that make up the bottom of BB-9E's head. The solid ring with the concave section (BB-9E_Bottom.stl) receives a single 6mmx3mm magnet. Be sure this magnet is aligned so that the poles match and attract the body magnets. Press the magnet in so it is flush with the inside of the concave part of the bottom. It will extend above the piece a bit, but there is room inside the bottom ring that will hold the extra height.

The segmented ring (BB-9E_Bottom_Ring.stl) holds three 6mmx3mm magnets. Before inserting the magnets add a length of wire that runs through the transverse hole between the rim and center hub. Cut the wire so it extends fully between that span (see photo). The photo shows stranded wire, but I ended up using wire wrap wire instead. it worked very well. Press the magnets in from the solid bottom side. Make sure the magnets extend just barely above the surface so the magnets can make solid contact with the magnets in the head. This will create a way to switch off the LED's in the head by rotating the top part of the head 90 degrees. Now you can nest the bottom to the bottom ring. The center magnet should be enough to hold them together, but I glued the two together using super glue.

This is the source for the 6mmx3mm magnets I used:

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01MXWMF7Q

Edit 3: Added the Dome Eye and Blue Lens for BB-9E's head. I used a 3mm white LED with a 120 ohm resistor attached to the positive lead of the LED (long leg). I then attached a length of red wire to the positive leg and used shrink wrap tubing to cover. This assembly will be inserted into the blue lens (BB9E-Blue_Lens.stl). I attached the LED assembly with super glue.

I used a 3mm red LED wired to a 200 ohm resistor attached to the long leg of the LED. I then attached a length of red wire to the positive leg and used shrink wrap tubing to cover. This assembly will be inserted into the Dome Eye (BB-9E_Head_Eye.stl). I attached the LED assembly with super glue.

I used the following LED's from Amazon:

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B018NQ77HG

The head (BB-9E_Head.stl) takes 5 of the magnets. In the next installment, I will include a wiring diagram.

More to follow!

I recommend using jpvanderendt's excellent stand design for your completed BB-9E: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1718534

author: jorgekarucha

description.text:
ESP-07 and ESP-12 modules are a little awkward to work with because the hole spacings are 2mm instead of breadboard friendly 2.54mm. You can buy breakout boards to help. I have some but the ones I have are so wide that in a normal breadboard they go into the outermost row of pins.

This adapter is more narrow so on the breadboard it leaves 2 holes on one side and 3 on the other. It works best with male-male pin headers with long pins on each side like in the 4th photo.

Update: Added photo of it in the breadboard as a programmer. Also in the breadboard was a ds18b20 temperature sensor. The socket seems to work fine for me without soldering.

Assembly

I designed this for the sockets I already had. They have 10 long flat pins. This only needs 8 pins
Steps:
1) Pull out the extra 2 pins in the connectors and cut of the extra plastic
2) With needle nose pliers Give each pin a quarter turn twist. This is so the narrow edge can slip into the half holes
3) With a fine drill (I used 1/32") open any of the holes that are closed on the first layer
4) Work each connector into the holes. This is a bit finicky work but not too hard
5) Straighten all the protruding pins so they are evenly spaced
6) I applied some hot glue to keep it together.
7) Bend the pins that stick through outwards (I used a vice) to allow easier insertion of module. Note the pins slide into the half holes on the edges, not through the holes.
8) Solder if you want something permanent. I leave one unsoldered as a programming socket.

Model showing details Model showing bending outwards of pins

Adjust in again and again for different materials, or change of nozzles, what ever. Use the adjuster to set the height, not the bed screw.

This is a special hook designed to hold flat objects with a hole. It was designed initially for a cutting board with a straight hole cut through. The goal of the hook was to have it sit flush with the hole, close to the wall, to not show any counter-sinked screws, and be pretty minimalistic.

title: AnySizeBearing - roller bearing/ball bearing fully parametrized
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2746804 is a nice idea. Thus I remodeled it in OpenSCAD to get a fully parametrized version.

Printer:

K8200

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.5 mm nozzle 0.2mm layers

Infill:

50%

Notes:

It is essential to check the slicer's G-code path for proper separation of rollers and shells over the full height. I printed the part directly and with a clearance of 0.1 mm.

After print it may be necessary to break off the rollers with gentle force using some small skrewdriver. Once all roller are free, operate the bearing carefully and remove all droplets and waste the printhead may have spilled.
Then lube with silicon grease or lithium spray and operate the inner shell with a dremel at higher speed until the outer shell starts to feel warm. Repeat this until the bearing runs smoothly.

The code

As the name AnySizeBearing promises, it lets you create a roller bearing with any inner and outer diameter, di, da and any height h. OK, there is some restriction in the code that enforces a minimal height and a minimal distance between the inner and outer diameter.

The call is simple. You specify the three measures and that's it:

 bearing(da=40, di=11.7, h=12);   // single unit

To simplify usage, the code automatically stacks up several instances, if the height is not representable by a single stage design. Further it also calculates the number and the radius of the rollers. Also note that I implemented a help_AnySizeBearing() function.

To test the code, I made a printout using a 0.5mm nozzle and 0.2mm layers. It came out well: see the video https://youtu.be/Lsn4va4d5Qc

In the parameter section you'll find some variables for customizing the output. In particular setting view_crossection to true, is quite helpful to preview exactly what get.

The library

As in my other projects I'm using the library shortcuts.scad to speed up my coding. It defines a bunch of macros that save about 75% of typing and a lot of brackets. It also features a help_shortcuts() function which outputs a cheat sheet to the console. For more information about its usage please refer to https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:644830

description.text:
Always felt if the original power supply for the Monoprice Mini Select needed a stand to raise it up to get air flow around it. So finally created a support for it.

The user will need to print at least two of these. One for each end. Also the design is such that you can print it vertical. No supports etc. As shown in the pictures.

No

0.175

80%

Notes:

The design pushes the printer but print it vertical like you see in the pictures. Will be a little ragged but the key areas print aok!

I places in the photos the Cura 2.3.1 settings I used.
No cleanup necessary. If you want you could trim the rough areas on the overhangs.

Blender and 3D printing do mix!

Been using Blender from Blender.org to do my CAD and 3D design work for over a year. Love that's its measurements are in MM which works well for this printer. Uses the Mirror function to make it easier to lay out.

Wanted something that looks nice and needed to test the printer after some tweaks on the Y Axes Belt. So this is the reason it looks like it came from a SciFi kit. A lot of odd and weird angles.

Have included along with the STL, the Blender file of this part. Have fun with it.

description.text:
This part is designed to clip onto the side of a wire dog playpen so it can be attached to a surface. I removed the clips joining the foldable metal pen sections, so it could block access to a wide entry way. The pen's wire has an approximate diameter of 3.7mm.

I snapped the printed parts onto the wire, then attached them to the wall with high strength velcro. The gap in the middle is for a small zip-tie, in case it needed a more robust connection to the wire.

If the length of the wire gate is too long, it's pretty easy to knock over; It's more of a deterrent.

Notes:

I printed this part vertically in order increase strength. Scale the part as needed, depending on the diameter of the wire and the accuracy of your printer.

Honeycomb like designs based off of an inputted image. The attached OpenSCAD script just needs a 2d array named "data" declared to work. This array is built by using the python script within the GitHub repo that takes in an image, converts it to grayscale, scales it, and spits out data based off of various options.

With no image data provided, the script will generate a random grid of hexagons. This should allow for simple use in the Customizer.

Also, be sure to export from OpenSCAD as AMF and not STL to avoid getting broken edges.

View the GitHub page for more: https://github.com/sluebbert/honeycombs

This is a mini hydro halo for starter pots. The outer diameter is 120mm and the ring thickness is 20mm. There are 5 customizable variables and they are as follows;

outsideDiameter = 120; //outermost diameter of the model
ringThickness = 20; //width of drip ring at the flat base

//-------------- For a Hooked loop, set inletPosition to 130, Opened = 0
inletPosition = 130; //rotational position of barb connector (0 = -Y)
startingDegreeFromY = -18; //Beginning angle of removed material
degreesOfRemoval = 36; //Number of degrees of material to be removed

To edit, you'll need to download and install OpenSCAD, but then a few quick value adjustments, press F6 to render, then Export STL once done. I'm certain you can make this as large as you want or as small as you want. The barb fitting is sized to mate with 1/2" poly tubing and I did not leave that value variable. If you want to though, feel free to locate that module and adjust accordingly.

I had difficulty printing this model with Simplify3D support materials, so I created my own custom support for the barb fitting. It appears this might not turn out well so I also rendered unsupported models of each as well. If you have your slicer generate the support structures, watch that they don't try and support the orifices as that will inhibit water flow.

Enjoy
